content: So, the summer beard is ready for a trim,
it looks like September's just around
the corner, so it's time for our next
Education in Chemistry. And this month we're
going to be visiting a demonstration that has
caused some life-changing injuries in
the US and has even had some calls for
it to be banned. But there's absolutely
no reason for this demonstration to be
banned as long as we're doing the
experiments safely and paying attention
especially to the choice of solvent. It's
recently been revisited by Peter Hoare
and CLEAPSS have issued a new risk
assessment to accompany this
demonstration so I thought it was
worthwhile flagging up; this is Rainbow Flames.
So, the main trick to doing this
demonstration safely is going to be
down to solvent choice. A lot of injuries
have been caused by using methanol in the past.
We're gonna be using ethanol today.
Number one: there's absolutely no reason
to be using methanol. It has an
incredibly low flash point and it's
actually toxic as well. So, ethanol, it's
going to be a much better choice for us
to be using. Also notice that I only
need like a maximum of 50 ml for this
demonstration, so I'm not gonna be
bringing a whole Winchester [bottle] load of
ethanol into the lab with me. This is as
much as I actually want to be around.
And the last thing of course, absolutely never, ever, ever pour straight from the bottle onto the experiment after it's begun.
We'll talk a little bit more
about that later on.
Okay so to get me started,
I have a number of salts here.
I've actually sort of arranged them
roughly in order of colour for the
rainbow but that's not obviously essential.
And into the bottom of each one
of these borosilicate beakers, I've
placed two to three grams of the solid.
Borosilicate is important to be using here to
make sure that the heat that is being
generated is not going to cause any cracks.
Watch glasses would be a really
poor choice for this experiment because
they tend to be made from soda glass.
It's likely that they will crack and
spill burning ethanol over your desk,
which of course you don't want to be
happening. So, having spread two or three
grams of the solid across the bottom,
then you just want to dampen each of the
solids with about half a ml of water.
I'm going to do that now.
And then on to each one you're going to
be using about six ml of ethanol.
Work on a heat-resistant mat for the
demonstration, and it would be handy to
have somebody ready nearby some light
switches to get the room darkened for you,
so that you can actually get the best
effect off of some of these flames.
So now I've got my beakers all loaded up
with solvent, next thing to do is to
make sure I remove the solvent at least
three metres away from where the
demonstration is taking place.
So I'm going to completely remove the bottle.
And at the same time, because I'm plugged
in here with a microphone, I'm going to
use that opportunity to make the room
a little bit darker so that we can enjoy
this experiment at the best possible
condition that we can.
Okay, so lights are down
I've got a metre rule with a
splint attached. My audience are three
metres away. I'm going to be using the
metre rule to light these up. Let's enjoy
the rainbow flames.
So, there we go, rainbow flames.
Now, before you go
the main risk associated with this
demonstration is when teachers attempted
to pour solvent straight back onto a
flame that they think has extinguished.
Potentially it has. But these beakers are
going to stay hot for at least 15
minutes afterwards make sure you do not
ever pour solvent straight back onto
these beakers. Leave them 15 minutes or
so. But if you've done that then actually
these beakers can be kept and reused
exactly as they are. It's a really quick
and simple demonstration to set up, with
the exception of the copper which will
thermally decompose. So that one actually
you would potentially collect and
dispose of but the other beakers you can
keep as they are. One last thing before
we go though: I got a new toy over the
summer and I was really excited by this.
It's a little computer spectrometer.
And I thought, well, this would be a great
demonstration to try and sort of see
what kind of data I can get from some
of these flames. I was particularly
interested in the potassium flame
because I was like I know that the
red line associated with lithium is that
nearest p down to the s transition.
And we get that nice bright famous sodium p
back down to the s transition.
Why isn't there this sort of same thing going on?
Why is it that potassium is such
a poor flame colour by comparison?
And then when I pointed the spectrometer at
the flame I was like I can't believe I
didn't think of this before. It was so
cool. Because I looked there and
isn't instead of seeing lots of
transitions around the purple end of
the spectrum I saw this massive
transition down in the red. It was the same p
to the s transition. I was like there's got to be something wrong with this
spectrometer. Until I looked more closely at
the numbers and it was borne out of
course when I went and checked out the
actual data for potassium. That same
p to s transition is there it's just
beyond the range of visible light to
the human eye. And so what we're seeing
here with the purple light coming from
the potassium are actually those far
more infrequent
transitions down from the higher
orbitals above that nearest p, which
explains of course why it's a paler
transitioned because they're happening
far more infrequently. And those
transitions are actually taking place in
the sodium and the lithium as well but
of course they're being masked by those
brighter lines coming from that very
common p down to s transition.
So, rainbow flames, it still can teach me a few things,
and I really hope it can enthuse your students as well.
Don't let this demonstration die,
it can be done safely. Get in touch with
CLEAPSS if you want any special guidance
and let's keep that flame burning for
Rainbow Flames. Thanks.
